dt: {bc}one who testifies in a cause or before a judicial tribunal
{bc}one asked to be present at a transaction so as to be able to testify to its having taken place
{bc}one who has personal knowledge of something
{bc}public affirmation by word or example of usually religious faith or conviction

et: Middle English {it}witnesse{/it}, from Old English {it}witnes{/it} knowledge, testimony, witness, from {et_link|wit:1|wit:1}
shortdef: attestation of a fact or event : testimony
one that gives evidence; specifically : one who testifies in a cause or before a judicial tribunal
one asked to be present at a transaction so as to be able to testify to its having taken place

dt: {bc}to have personal or direct cognizance of {bc}see for oneself

dt.t: our grammar—{wi}witness{/wi} our verb system—is a marvel of flexibility, variety, and exactitude

dt: {bc}to constitute the scene or time of

dt.t: structures … which this striking Dorset hilltop once {wi}witnessed{/wi}

dt: {bc}to bear witness to one's religious convictions

pt: {sc}certify{/sc} {sc}attest{/sc} {sc}witness{/sc} {sc}vouch{/sc} mean to testify to the truth or genuineness of something. {sc}certify{/sc} usually applies to a written statement, especially one carrying a signature or seal.

pt.t: {it}certified{/it} that the candidate had met all requirements

pt: {sc}attest{/sc} applies to oral or written testimony usually from experts or witnesses.

pt.t: {it}attested{/it} to the authenticity of the document

pt: {sc}witness{/sc} applies to the subscribing of one's own name to a document as evidence of its genuineness.
{sc}vouch{/sc} applies to one who testifies as a competent authority or a reliable person.

shortdef: to act as legal witness of

dt: {bc}an enclosure in which a witness sits or stands while testifying in court

shortdef: an enclosure in which a witness sits or stands while testifying in court

dt: {bc}a stand or an enclosure from which a witness gives evidence in a court

shortdef: a stand or an enclosure from which a witness gives evidence in a court

dt: {bc}the act of physically harming or using threats, intimidation, harassment, or corrupt persuasion against a witness with the goal of influencing the witness's testimony or preventing the witness from providing evidence in an official proceeding

dt.t: …12 jurors are considering whether to put him in prison for the rest of his life on charges that include racketeering, extortion, bribery, mail fraud and {wi}witness tampering{/wi}.

shortdef: the act of physically harming or using threats, intimidation, harassment, or corrupt persuasion against a witness with the goal of influencing the witness's testimony or preventing the witness from providing evidence in an official proceeding

dt: {bc}a witness upon whom a criminal defendant relies in establishing or providing an alibi

shortdef: a witness upon whom a criminal defendant relies in establishing or providing an alibi

dt: {bc}a person who gives evidence in a legal action concerning the reputation, conduct, and moral nature of a party

shortdef: a person who gives evidence in a legal action concerning the reputation, conduct, and moral nature of a party

dt: {bc}a member of a group that witness by distributing literature and by personal evangelism to beliefs in the theocratic rule of God, the sinfulness of organized religions and governments, and an imminent millennium

shortdef: a member of a group that witness by distributing literature and by personal evangelism to beliefs in the theocratic rule of God, the sinfulness of organized religions and governments, and an imminent millennium

dt: {bc}to show that something exists or is true

dt.t: His success {it}bears witness to{/it} the value of hard work.
Rising ticket sales {it}bear witness to{/it} the band's popularity.

dt: {bc}to make a statement saying that one saw or knows something

dt.t: asked to {phrase}bear witness{/phrase} to the facts
She was accused of {phrase}bearing false witness{/phrase} at the trial.

shortdef: to show that something exists or is true —+ to
to make a statement saying that one saw or knows something

dt.t: We have {it}been witness to{/it} many changes in recent years.
